Group feature extractionÂ¶

[1]:

import movekit as mkit
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

[2]:

path = "./datasets/fish-5-features.csv"
data = mkit.read_data(path)
data.head()

Detecting outliersÂ¶

Function performs detection of outliers, based on userâs criteria, regarding features, method and share of outliers.

[3]:

outs = mkit.outlier_detection(data)

# printing all rows where outliers are present
outs[outs.loc[:,"outlier"] == 1]

[4]:

# same function, different parameters
other_outs = mkit.outlier_detection(dataset = data, features = ["average_speed", "average_acceleration"], contamination = 0.05, n_neighbors = 8, method = "median", metric = "euclidean")

# printing all rows where outliers are present
other_outs[other_outs.loc[:,"outlier"] == 1].head()

Group-level AnalysisÂ¶

Below we perform Analysis on Group-Level. This consists of: - Group-Level averages, - Centroid Medoid computation - A dynamic time warping matrix, - A clustering over time based on absolute features, - The centroid direction, - The heading difference of each animal with respect to the current centroid - The group - polarization for each timestep.

Obtain group-level records for each point in timeÂ¶

Records consist of total group-distance, mean-speed mean-acceleration and mean distance from centroid. If input doesnât contain centroid or feature data, it is calculated, showing a warning. Parameter object_output produces a post gis - compatible point.

[5]:

group_data = mkit.group_movement(data)
group_data.head()

c:\users\manuel\appdata\local\programs\python\python38\lib\site-packages\movekit\feature_extraction.py:297: UserWarning: Recalculating centroid-distances, since not found in input dataset!
  warnings.warn(

[5]:
total_dist mean_speed mean_acceleration mean_distance_centroid
time

4 0.918960 0.153579 -0.000339 29.7782

Obtain centroid, medoid and distance to centroidÂ¶

Parameter options go either for each unit per timestamp or as post-gis compatible object

[6]:

movement = mkit.centroid_medoid_computation(data, object_output = False)
movement.head()

[6]:

Get the centroid directionÂ¶

If no centroid coordinates are found in input, function calculates centroids first, emitting a warning.

[7]:

centroid_dir = mkit.compute_centroid_direction(data).sort_values(['time','animal_id'])
centroid_dir.head(10)

Getting the heading differenceÂ¶

Calculate the difference in degrees between the animalâs direction and the centroidâs direction for each timestep. Stronger gain in y gives positive difference, weaker gain in y gives negative difference, since constant y is defined to be 0 degrees.

[8]:

heading_diff = mkit.get_heading_difference(data)
heading_diff.head()

[8]:
time animal_id outlier x y distance average_speed average_acceleration direction stopped x_centroid y_centroid medoid distance_to_centroid centroid_direction heading_difference
0 1 312 0 405.29 417.76 0.000000 0.210217 -0.018039 0.000000 1 395.364 423.226 312 11.331 NaN NaN
1 2 312 0 405.31 417.37 0.390512 0.192177 -0.018039 -87.064327 1 395.382 423.220 312 11.523 -18.434949 -68.629378
2 3 312 0 405.31 417.07 0.300000 0.174723 -0.018039 -90.000000 1 395.392 423.234 312 11.677 54.462322 -144.462322
3 4 312 0 405.30 416.86 0.210238 0.159133 -0.018039 -92.726311 1 395.396 423.272 312 11.798 83.990994 -176.717305
4 5 312 0 405.29 416.71 0.150333 0.155506 -0.018039 -93.814075 1 395.394 423.324 312 11.903 92.202598 173.983327

Computing polarizationÂ¶

Computing polarization of animals for each timestep. Value is between 0 and 1

[9]:

pol = mkit.compute_polarization(data)
pol.head()

[9]:

4 5 312 0 405.29 416.71 0.150333 0.155506 -0.018039 -93.814075 1 0.037233

Obtain a matrix, based on dynamic time warpingÂ¶

Each Animal-ID is displayed in the indices, the entries reflect the similarity of the animalâs trajectories based on the DTW algorithm.

[10]:

mkit.dtw_matrix(data)

[10]:
312 511 607 811 905
